decision_name: EU Digital Crisis Response Platform Investment

context.business_challenge: Increasing frequency of supply chain disruptions and product safety incidents across EU markets requires enhanced crisis response capabilities
context.market_conditions: EU regulatory requirements (GDPR, product safety directives) demand rapid crisis communication and response
context.competitive_pressure: Leading EU retailers have implemented AI-powered crisis management platforms
context.internal_capabilities: Current manual crisis response processes are slow and inconsistent across 15 EU countries

alternatives.name: Full Platform Implementation
alternatives.description: Deploy comprehensive AI-powered crisis management platform across all EU operations

alternatives.name: Phased Regional Rollout
alternatives.description: Implement platform in high-risk markets first (Germany, France, UK) then expand

alternatives.name: Enhanced Manual Processes
alternatives.description: Upgrade existing manual processes with better tools and training

evaluation_criteria.measurement: Time from crisis detection to stakeholder notification
ROI and cost savings from crisis mitigation
Ability to handle multiple simultaneous crises

rationale: Balances investment risk with comprehensive coverage, allows learning from pilot implementation, and ensures regulatory compliance across EU markets

implementation_plan.phase_1: Pilot in Germany and France (6 months)
implementation_plan.phase_2: Expand to UK and Netherlands (12 months)

risk_mitigation: Conduct thorough data privacy impact assessment
Create rollback procedures for implementation issues
lessons_learned: Early stakeholder engagement crucial for EU regulatory compliance
Phased approach reduces risk while building capabilities
Digital transformation requires cultural change management
ROI measurement should include regulatory compliance savings
